questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a follow-up examination. She has a history of recurrent asthma attacks. The mother reports that her daughter has also had mild abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. The patient's current medications include daily inhaled fluticasone and inhaled albuterol as needed. She appears well. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Abdominal examination shows a left-sided, nontender, smooth abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) may manifest in some cases as a palpable abdominal mass or a protruding abdomen due to renal enlargement. Cystic diseases of the kidneys account for ∼ 5% of all palpable abdominal masses in children. However, polycystic kidney disease generally involves both kidneys concomitantly and is usually not an incidental finding, but rather manifests with hematuria, signs of renal failure (e.g., electrolyte disturbances, increased serum creatinine and BUN), and/or recurrent urinary tract infections.
Image Description:

Left kidney

Multiple fluid-filled cysts of various sizes are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

In children, lymphomas that arise as palpable abdominal masses are typically non-Hodgkin lymphomas of the GI tract, e.g., Burkitt lymphomas. Such large lymphomas usually manifest with concomitant symptoms of mass effect, such as bowel obstruction, intussusception, constipation, or decreased appetite. Additionally, more than 50% of pediatric gastrointestinal lymphomas arise in the ileocecal region, manifesting as an RLQ mass. While lymphoma cannot be entirely excluded in this patient solely based on the findings presented, it is not the most likely cause of an abdominal mass in this 4-year-old girl.

C) INCORRECT:

In this patient's age group, acute leukemia usually takes the form of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the most common malignant disease in childhood. Leukemia can manifest with palpable hepatomegaly and/or splenomegaly as a result of leukemic infiltration, which could mimic an abdominal mass. However, patients with ALL are usually acutely ill, manifesting with symptoms of fever, weight loss, bone marrow infiltration (anemia, bleeding, or recurrent infections), and corresponding lab findings, as well as painless generalized lymphadenopathy and/or bone pain.

D) CORRECT:

Nephroblastoma, or Wilms tumor, should be suspected in a young child with a nontender abdominal mass that does not cross the midline, especially if its surface is smooth, as is the case in this patient. Nephroblastoma is the fourth most common type of childhood cancer, accounting for ∼ 5% of all malignant childhood tumors. The tumor is most commonly an incidental finding on exam, without other signs or symptoms, but may manifest with abdominal pain and hypertension. Laboratory analysis should include a urinalysis, which typically shows hematuria. The best initial diagnostic test is an abdominal ultrasound, which can distinguish nephroblastoma from other abdominal tumors, showing a kidney mass of mostly uniform echogenicity with hypoechoic areas of necrosis. Abdominal CT or MRI is performed to assess the extent of involvement and to help with surgical planning.
Image Description:

MRI abdomen (T2-weighted with fat saturation; coronal plane) of a 3-year-old child

A large heterogeneous but relatively well-circumscribed solid mass is centered within the lower pole of the left kidney. Normal renal tissue is seen cranial to the mass. The hypointense areas of the mass suggest soft tissue, whereas the areas of hyperintensity suggest hemorrhage or necrosis.

Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor), the most common type of pediatric renal cancer, with a peak incidence at 3–4 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastoma is the third most common malignancy of childhood; it should be among the differential diagnoses in any child presenting with an abdominal mass. However, neuroblastoma typically manifests before the second year of life as an irregular abdominal mass that often crosses the midline (unlike this patient's mass) and is often associated with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, failure to thrive).

F) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common kidney cancer in adults, but it is rare during childhood and adolescence, accounting for ∼ 2% of all pediatric renal tumors. While RCC can manifest with a palpable mass in the flank or the abdomen, it is usually also associated with hematuria, anemia, and constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue, fever).

G) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cysts can occasionally grow very large and may even be palpable as a unilateral lower abdominal and/or pelvic mass, which is often associated with lower abdominal pain. But premenstrual ovarian cysts are very rare and usually manifest with other symptoms of pelvic mass effect, such as urinary frequency or constipation.
questions.hint: This patient's condition may be associated with aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and intellectual disability as part of WAGR syndrome.

questions.text: A 4700-g (10.3-lb) male newborn is delivered at 37 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn appears pale. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows midfacial hypoplasia, infraorbital creases, and a large tongue. The right side of the body is larger than the left. Abdominal examination shows that the abdominal viscera protrudes through the abdominal wall at the umbilicus; the viscera are covered by the amniotic membrane and the peritoneum. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 48 mg/dL. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows enlarged kidneys bilaterally. In addition to surgical closure of the abdominal wall, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IGF-1 with elevated growth hormone levels is diagnostic of a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma, which can present as gigantism in children. It would be very rare, however, for a newborn to present with a pituitary adenoma, which would also not explain this boy's hemihyperplasia and omphalocele. Serum IGF-1 has no diagnostic utility in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Deregulation of the IGF-2 gene, however, is one of several genes implicated in the development of the syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Low free T4 levels would confirm hypothyroidism, which can be associated with macroglossia and abdominal wall defects (most commonly umbilical hernias). In congenital hypothyroidism, however, a newborn would not be expected to be large for gestational age nor have signs of hemihyperplasia or organomegaly.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels confirm the diagnosis of 21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency, the most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Although patients with 21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency can have hypoglycemia during a salt-losing adrenal crisis, other findings would also be expected (e.g., hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia). Furthermore, male neonates with congenital adrenal hyperplasia do not usually have any physical anomalies (i.e., macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, or organomegaly), which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A growth hormone-producing pituitary adenoma, which can result in organomegaly and a newborn being large for gestational age, can be diagnosed with a cranial MRI. It would be extremely rare, however, for a neonate to present with a pituitary adenoma. Cranial MRI has no diagnostic utility in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which is the most likely diagnosis here. A baseline MRI of the abdomen to screen for tumors should be considered and would likely be part of the workup for this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at increased risk for various tumors, including nephroblastoma, hepatoblastoma, and neuroblastoma. Abdominal ultrasounds with views of the kidneys are recommended every 3 months until 8 years of age to screen for these tumors. Additionally, serum α-fetoprotein levels should also be measured every 2–3 months until 4 years of age to screen for hepatoblastoma. Although measurement of urinary catecholamines has been proposed as a screening method for neuroblastomas, it has not been incorporated into most protocols.

F) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping can confirm the diagnosis of various genetic disorders, including trisomy 13 and trisomy 18, both of which can be associated with omphalocele. This patient, however, does not have other features of trisomy 13 (e.g., microphthalmia, polydactyly, and congenital heart defects) or trisomy 18 (e.g., prominent occiput, low-set ears, micrognathia, and rocker-bottom feet). In addition, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by deregulation of imprinting in certain genes, which would not be detected with karyotyping.
questions.hint: This newborn is large for gestational age and presents with facial abnormalities, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, organomegaly, and hypoglycemia. These features are consistent with the diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of swelling around the eyelids. He was born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is at the 95th percentile for weight and 60th percentile for length. His blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an empty scrotal sac and a left-sided abdominal mass. Ophthalmologic examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows proteinuria of 3+ and fatty casts. Abdominal ultrasound shows a hypervascular mass at the upper pole of the left kidney. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient's disease?

choices.text: Increased expression of insulin-like growth factor 2
Deletion of a gene on chromosome 11
Point mutation of the WT1 gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased activity of hypoxia-inducible factor 1-α is seen in von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL), a condition that predisposes to the development of renal masses like pheochromocytoma and renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Both pheochromocytoma and RCC can lead to hypertension, which is seen in this patient. However, a hypervascular renal tumor in a 1-yr-old infant is more consistent with nephroblastoma, which is not associated with VHL. Also, cryptorchidism and features of nephrotic syndrome would not be expected. Instead, patients with VHL develop mucocutaneous and/or visceral hemangiomas.

B) INCORRECT:

17α-hydroxylase deficiency can cause cryptorchidism in males and hypertension, which is seen here, and a mass at the upper pole of the kidney (enlarged adrenal gland). However, both the adrenal glands would be enlarged in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency unlike this patient with a unilateral mass, and features of nephrotic syndrome would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) is associated with increased expression of insulin-like growth factor 2 due to a defect in the WT2 gene on chromosome 11. Patients with BWS are typically overweight and BWS can result in nephroblastoma, as seen here. However, cryptorchidism and features of nephrotic syndrome would not be expected. Instead, features such as macroglossia, tall stature or hemihypertrophy, and organomegaly would be present. This patient's condition is most likely caused by a mutation in the WT1 gene.

D) INCORRECT:

Deletion of the entire WT1 gene on chromosome 11 leads to WAGR syndrome, which could account for this patient's nephroblastoma, nephrotic syndrome, and cryptorchidism. However, aniridia, which is characteristic of WAGR syndrome, has not been reported in this patient. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a point mutation rather than deletion of the WT1 gene.

E) CORRECT:

Denys-Drash syndrome is caused by a point mutation of the WT1 gene on chromosome 11, which encodes a zinc finger transcription factor. This transcription factor is crucial for renal and genital development and loss of function of the WT1 gene would result in the symptoms described here. WAGR syndrome, which is associated with a deletion of the WT1 gene, would present similarly but an infant with WAGR would typically have aniridia on examination. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) is another cause of nephroblastoma. However, BWS is caused by a mutation in the WT2 gene and is not associated with cryptorchidism or nephrotic syndrome.
questions.hint: An empty scrotal sac or male pseudohermaphroditism (due to gonadal dysgenesis), nephroblastoma (hypervascular renal tumor of childhood), and symptoms of nephrotic syndrome (periorbital swelling, weight gain, hypertension, proteinuria with fatty casts) are consistent with Denys-Drash syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old mother, gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The patient's Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively. Family history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and open-angle glaucoma in his father. He appears well. He is at the 80th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 150/min, and respirations are 44/min. Genitourinary examination shows abnormal foreskin and two meatal openings. Examination of the eyes shows partial absence of the iris. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain may be used to screen for neuroblastoma, which occurs in several genetic syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, neurofibromatosis, Hirschsprung disease). This patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk for another condition.

B) CORRECT:

Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor) is associated with WAGR syndrome. Approximately 50% of children with WAGR syndrome develop nephroblastoma; therefore, screening ultrasound should be obtained quarterly until at least five years of age. Treatment typically consists of surgical resection and chemotherapy; radiation therapy is possible in advanced stages. Nephroblastoma has a good prognosis with survival rates > 90%.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of metanephrines (via serum or 24-hour urine collection) is used to screen for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. Screening for pheochromocytoma is not recommended until 11 years of age, and this patient is a newborn. Moreover, this patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk of a different condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis is used in the workup of Denys-Drash syndrome, which manifests with genitourinary abnormalities (e.g., undescended testis), early-onset nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria, and nephroblastoma. This patient's presentation is consistent with WAGR syndrome, for which screening urinalysis is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Alpha-fetoprotein measurements can be used to screen for hepatoblastoma, which is associated with several genetic syndromes (e.g., Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, Trisomy 18, Trisomy 21), and yolk sac tumors. This patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk of another condition.
questions.hint: This patient's aniridia and genitourinary anomaly (hypospadias) suggest WAGR syndrome.

questions.text:
A healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an abdominal mass. Her parents report that she has had abdominal pain and decreased appetite for the past 3 weeks and that her abdomen seems more protuberant. When they were bathing her this morning, they thought they might have felt something hard under her ribs. She has not had any weight loss, fevers, or change in bowel habits.
On examination, she is playful and appears well. She has a heart rate of 97 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 92/56 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 100% while breathing ambient air. Palpation of the right upper quadrant reveals a hard, nontender mass that extends about 4 cm below the costal margin. Her abdomen is distended but otherwise soft. The rest of her examination is normal.
Laboratory results, including a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel, are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intussusception (the telescoping of part of the intestine into itself) typically occurs before 2 years of age and often manifests with the triad of colicky abdominal pain, a sausage-shaped abdominal mass in the right upper quadrant, and jelly-red stools. Most patients with intussusception are irritable and have vomiting; about 25% have an abdominal mass. The telescoping of the intestine can be visualized on ultrasound as the classic target sign.

B) INCORRECT:

Although hepatoblastoma is the most common liver tumor in children and the third most common abdominal tumor in children aged 6 months to 3 years, it is a much less frequent diagnosis than either Wilms tumor or neuroblastoma. Patients with hepatoblastoma typically have anemia, thrombocytosis, and elevated aminotransferase levels, none of which are present in this patient. They also tend to have an elevated alpha-fetoprotein level.

C) CORRECT:

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) is the most common solid renal tumor in childhood and the most likely cause of an abdominal mass in an otherwise healthy child between the ages of 1 and 5 years. Almost all cases have unilateral kidney involvement and are diagnosed before 10 years of age (mean age, 3 years). Affected children often present with an asymptomatic abdominal mass discovered incidentally by a caregiver or pediatrician, but symptoms can include abdominal distention, anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, fever, and hematuria. About 25% of children with Wilms tumor have hypertension at diagnosis. Unlike neuroblastoma or sarcoma, Wilms tumor rarely invades bone or bone marrow; consequently, patients do not have low blood-cell counts, bone pain, or fractures, even at advanced stages.

About 10% of Wilms tumors occur as part of a genetic cancer-predisposition syndrome such as WAGR syndrome (Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary malformation, intellectual disability) or an overgrowth syndrome such as Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. WT1, a tumor suppressor gene, has been associated with many Wilms tumors.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of an abdominal mass in an otherwise healthy 3-year-old child with normal vital signs and normal laboratory results is Wilms tumor.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal-cell carcinoma, the most common malignancy of renal origin in adults, is rare in children. When it does occur in this population, it is most commonly seen in older children and adolescents, and they typically present with advanced disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Sarcomas, particularly rhabdomyosarcoma, can manifest in childhood as a painless mass, but these tumors are typically seen in children older than 5 years of age.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy with global developmental delay and a history of a repaired undescended testicle presents to the emergency department for evaluation of an abdominal mass that his parents noticed while bathing him last night. His vital signs are within normal limits for his age. A firm, smooth, nontender mass is palpated to the left of midline.
Which one of the following findings could be associated with this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal cysts are associated with many genetic disorders and childhood syndromes, including polycystic kidney disease, oro-facial-digital syndrome, and RCAD (renal cysts and diabetes). Renal cysts are usually asymptomatic and found incidentally on ultrasound (often prenatally). They may manifest with signs of kidney injury (such as electrolyte abnormalities or elevated creatinine) but do not manifest as asymptomatic palpable masses.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 is associated with a predisposition to tumors of the parathyroid gland, pituitary, and pancreas but is not associated with abdominal tumors.

C) CORRECT:

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) is the most likely cause of an abdominal mass in an otherwise healthy child between the ages of 1 and 5 years. Affected children often present with an asymptomatic abdominal mass discovered incidentally by a caregiver or pediatrician, but symptoms can include abdominal distention, anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, fever, and hematuria. About 10% of Wilms tumors occur as part of a genetic cancer-predisposition syndrome such as WAGR syndrome (Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary malformation, intellectual disability) or an overgrowth syndrome such as Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. In this case, the patient’s clinical presentation should raise suspicion for Wilms tumor, and the combination of this tumor with intellectual disability and a genitourinary anomaly (cryptorchidism) suggests the possibility of WAGR syndrome. WAGR syndrome is caused by a chromosomal deletion of the WT1 gene located at 11p13. This gene is a transcription factor involved in gonadal and renal development.

Key learning point: The presence of an abdominal mass in a toddler with cryptorchidism and intellectual disability should raise suspicion for WAGR (Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary malformation, intellectual disability) syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Café au lait macules are typical clinical manifestations of neurofibromatosis type 1, an autosomal dominant disorder that predisposes children to fibromas but is not associated with Wilms tumor. Café au lait macules can also be seen with McCune-Albright syndrome, which is associated with endocrine hyperfunctioning and fibrous dysplasia but not the clinical features seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Short thumbs are seen with Fanconi anemia, which is associated with developmental delay and the VACTERL-H association (which is defined as at least three of the following: vertebral anomalies, anal atresia, cardiac anomalies, tracheoesophageal fistula, esophageal atresia, renal anomalies, limb anomalies, and hydrocephalus). Fanconi anemia is associated with an increased risk of malignancy, including solid tumors, but such tumors are rare in young children.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for a follow-up examination. The mother reports that her daughter has also had mild abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a left-sided, nontender, smooth abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) may manifest in some cases as a palpable abdominal mass or a protruding abdomen due to renal enlargement. Cystic diseases of the kidneys account for ∼ 5% of all palpable abdominal masses in children. However, polycystic kidney disease generally involves both kidneys concomitantly and is usually not an incidental finding, but rather manifests with hematuria, signs of renal failure (e.g., electrolyte disturbances, increased serum creatinine and BUN), and/or recurrent urinary tract infections.
Image Description:

Left kidney

Multiple fluid-filled cysts of various sizes are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

In children, lymphomas that arise as palpable abdominal masses are typically non-Hodgkin lymphomas of the GI tract, e.g., Burkitt lymphomas. Such large lymphomas usually manifest with concomitant symptoms of mass effect, such as bowel obstruction, intussusception, constipation, or decreased appetite. Additionally, more than 50% of pediatric gastrointestinal lymphomas arise in the ileocecal region, manifesting as an RLQ mass. While lymphoma cannot be entirely excluded in this patient solely based on the findings presented, it is not the most likely cause of an abdominal mass in this 4-year-old girl.

C) CORRECT:

Nephroblastoma, or Wilms tumor, should be suspected in a young child with a nontender abdominal mass that does not cross the midline, especially if its surface is smooth, as is the case in this patient. Nephroblastoma is the fourth most common type of childhood cancer, accounting for ∼ 5% of all malignant childhood tumors. The tumor is most commonly an incidental finding on exam, without other signs or symptoms, but may manifest with abdominal pain and hypertension. Laboratory analysis should include a urinalysis, which typically shows hematuria. The best initial diagnostic test is an abdominal ultrasound, which can distinguish nephroblastoma from other abdominal tumors, showing a kidney mass of mostly uniform echogenicity with hypoechoic areas of necrosis. Abdominal CT or MRI is performed to assess the extent of involvement and to help with surgical planning.
Image Description:

MRI abdomen (T2-weighted with fat saturation; coronal plane) of a 3-year-old child

A large heterogeneous but relatively well-circumscribed solid mass is centered within the lower pole of the left kidney. Normal renal tissue is seen cranial to the mass. The hypointense areas of the mass suggest soft tissue, whereas the areas of hyperintensity suggest hemorrhage or necrosis.

Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor), the most common type of pediatric renal cancer, with a peak incidence at 3–4 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastoma is the third most common malignancy of childhood; it should be among the differential diagnoses in any child presenting with an abdominal mass. However, neuroblastoma typically manifests before the second year of life as an irregular abdominal mass that often crosses the midline (unlike this patient's mass) and is often associated with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, failure to thrive).

E) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common kidney cancer in adults, but it is rare during childhood and adolescence, accounting for ∼ 2% of all pediatric renal tumors. While RCC can manifest with a palpable mass in the flank or the abdomen, it is usually also associated with hematuria, anemia, and constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue, fever).
questions.hint: This patient's condition may be associated with aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and intellectual disability as part of WAGR syndrome.

questions.text: A healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an abdominal mass. Her parents report that she has had abdominal pain and decreased appetite for the past 3 weeks and that her abdomen seems more protuberant. On examination, she is playful and appears well. Palpation of the right upper quadrant reveals a hard, nontender mass that extends about 4 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory results, including a complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel, are normal. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intussusception (the telescoping of part of the intestine into itself) typically occurs before 2 years of age and often manifests with the triad of colicky abdominal pain, a sausage-shaped abdominal mass in the right upper quadrant, and jelly-red stools. Most patients with intussusception are irritable and have vomiting; about 25% have an abdominal mass. The telescoping of the intestine can be visualized on ultrasound as the classic target sign.

B) INCORRECT:

Although hepatoblastoma is the most common liver tumor in children and the third most common abdominal tumor in children aged 6 months to 3 years, it is a much less frequent diagnosis than either Wilms tumor or neuroblastoma. Patients with hepatoblastoma typically have anemia, thrombocytosis, and elevated aminotransferase levels, none of which are present in this patient. They also tend to have an elevated alpha-fetoprotein level.

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) is the most common solid renal tumor in childhood and the most likely cause of an abdominal mass in an otherwise healthy child between the ages of 1 and 5 years. Almost all cases have unilateral kidney involvement and are diagnosed before 10 years of age (mean age, 3 years). Affected children often present with an asymptomatic abdominal mass discovered incidentally by a caregiver or pediatrician, but symptoms can include abdominal distention, anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, fever, and hematuria. About 25% of children with Wilms tumor have hypertension at diagnosis. Unlike neuroblastoma or sarcoma, Wilms tumor rarely invades bone or bone marrow; consequently, patients do not have low blood-cell counts, bone pain, or fractures, even at advanced stages.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of an abdominal mass in an otherwise healthy 3-year-old child with normal vital signs and normal laboratory results is Wilms tumor.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal-cell carcinoma, the most common malignancy of renal origin in adults, is rare in children. When it does occur in this population, it is most commonly seen in older children and adolescents, and they typically present with advanced disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Sarcomas, particularly rhabdomyosarcoma, can manifest in childhood as a painless mass, but these tumors are typically seen in children older than 5 years of age.
questions.hint: This condition should be suspected in a toddler with a non-tender abdominal mass, especially if it is firm, smooth, and associated with hematuria and/or hypertension.

questions.text: A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old mother, gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The patient's Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively. He is at the 80th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 150/min, and respirations are 44/min. Genitourinary examination shows abnormal foreskin and two meatal openings. Examination of the eyes shows partial absence of the iris. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain may be used to screen for neuroblastoma, which occurs in several genetic syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, neurofibromatosis, Hirschsprung disease). This patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk for another condition.

B) CORRECT:

Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor) is associated with WAGR syndrome. Approximately 50% of children with WAGR syndrome develop nephroblastoma; therefore, screening ultrasound should be obtained quarterly until at least five years of age. Treatment typically consists of surgical resection and chemotherapy; radiation therapy is possible in advanced stages. Nephroblastoma has a good prognosis with survival rates > 90%.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of metanephrines (via serum or 24-hour urine collection) is used to screen for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. Screening for pheochromocytoma is not recommended until 11 years of age, and this patient is a newborn. Moreover, this patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk of a different condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis is used in the workup of Denys-Drash syndrome, which manifests with genitourinary abnormalities (e.g., undescended testis), early-onset nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria, and nephroblastoma. This patient's presentation is consistent with WAGR syndrome, for which screening urinalysis is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Alpha-fetoprotein measurements can be used to screen for hepatoblastoma, which is associated with several genetic syndromes (e.g., Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, Trisomy 18, Trisomy 21), and yolk sac tumors. This patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk of another condition.
questions.hint: This patient's aniridia and genitourinary anomaly (hypospadias) suggest WAGR syndrome.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of abdominal swelling noticed by his mother while bathing him. He has no fever, distress, or pain. Past medical history is unremarkable. He has a congenital anomaly: partial absence of the iris on the left eye. Physical examination reveals a firm, non-tender, smooth mass in the left flank (see lab result and report).

Blood pressure
110/70 mmHg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 Erythrocytes
5 per high power field
0 - 2 per high power field



Ultrasound: Well-defined solid mass arising from the left kidney
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common renal malignancy in children under 5 years of age. It typically presents with a painless abdominal mass. The ultrasound finding of a well-defined solid mass originating from the kidney supports this diagnosis. The presence of microscopic hematuria suggests renal involvement. Additionally, the congenital ocular anomaly, partial absence of the iris, aligns with WAGR syndrome, which includes Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and intellectual disability. These clinical features and associations strongly indicate Wilms tumor.

Key learning point: Wilms' tumor (nephroblastoma) in children can present with a painless abdominal mass, hematuria, and is associated with syndromic features such as aniridia and genitourinary abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastoma often presents with an abdominal mass in children, but it typically originates from the adrenal medulla, not the kidney. The ultrasound shows a mass arising from the kidney, which is inconsistent with neuroblastoma. The congenital ocular anomaly is more indicative of syndromic renal tumors, not neuroblastoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic kidney disease typically presents with bilateral kidney enlargement and multiple cysts, not a solitary solid mass. The ultrasound identifies a single solid lesion, which is inconsistent with the cystic nature of polycystic kidney disease. The congenital ocular anomaly is not associated with this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydronephrosis manifests as a dilated collecting system filled with fluid, not a solid mass. The ultrasound describes a well-defined solid mass, which is inconsistent with hydronephrosis. Additionally, hydronephrosis often presents with symptoms of urinary obstruction, which are absent here.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the Pediatric Clinic by his mother due to a painless abdominal swelling noticed during bathing. Over the past 2 weeks, she has also observed occasional drops of blood in his urine. He was previously healthy with normal developmental milestones and has no fever, night sweats, or weight loss (see lab result and report).

Blood pressure
104/65 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 Erythrocytes
10 per high power field
0 - 2 per high power field



Abdominal ultrasound: Well-defined, unilateral renal mass
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastoma, a malignancy of neural crest origin, typically arises in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia. It often presents as an irregular, heterogeneous mass that may cross the midline and show calcifications. Systemic symptoms like fever and weight loss are common, unlike the isolated hematuria and well-defined renal mass seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydronephrosis results from urinary tract obstruction, leading to dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces, seen as anechoic spaces on ultrasound. The well-defined renal mass described here does not match the diffuse appearance of hydronephrosis. Additionally, hydronephrosis often presents with obstructive symptoms, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma is rare in children, especially at age 3, and typically occurs in older individuals. Pediatric cases often involve genetic predispositions or older children. The well-defined renal mass on ultrasound is more characteristic of pediatric renal tumors like Wilms tumor, rather than the heterogeneous features of renal cell carcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

Wilms tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common renal malignancy in early childhood, typically presenting between ages 2 and 5 years. It manifests with a painless abdominal mass, often discovered incidentally, and may be accompanied by hematuria due to tumor invasion into renal tissue. Ultrasound imaging usually reveals a well-circumscribed, unilateral renal mass. The tumor originates from embryonic renal tissue and may show a triphasic histologic pattern with blastemal, epithelial, and stromal components. These clinical and imaging features are crucial for diagnosing and managing Wilms tumor.

Key learning point: Wilms tumor is a common pediatric renal tumor that presents with an abdominal mass, hematuria, and sometimes hypertension, without systemic symptoms like fever or weight loss.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic because of a swelling on the left side of his abdomen. He has no oral intake issues or vomiting. He appears well, with no fever or significant weight loss. Examination reveals a firm, non-tender mass in the left flank that does not cross the midline (see lab result and reports).

Blood pressure
130/80 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 Erythrocytes
5 per high power field
0 - 2 per high power field




Ultrasound of abdomen: Solitary, well-defined mass arising from the left kidney, displacing the renal pelvis but sparing the contralateral kidney
Chest X-ray: Normal

Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastoma typically originates from the adrenal medulla or sympathetic nervous tissue, not the kidney. The mass is generally irregular, may contain calcifications, and often crosses the midline. The imaging identifies a well-defined, solitary mass arising from the left kidney, consistent with a primary renal lesion. Hematuria supports a renal-origin pathology rather than a tumor of adrenal or paraspinal origin.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma is exceptionally rare in early childhood and typically occurs in older adults. Although microscopic hematuria and increased blood pressure might be associated with renal neoplasms, these findings are not exclusive to renal cell carcinoma. The imaging description of a solitary, well-defined mass confined to one kidney aligns more with pediatric neoplasms.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydronephrosis is characterized by dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces due to urinary outflow obstruction, manifesting as an anechoic, fluid-filled expansion rather than a discrete mass. The ultrasound reports a solitary, well-defined mass arising from the left kidney, indicating a lesion from the renal parenchyma. The firm, non-tender mass does not align with the usual soft appearance of hydronephrosis.

D) CORRECT:

Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common renal malignancy in early childhood, typically presenting between ages 2 and 5 years. It manifests with a firm, non-tender mass in the flank that remains confined to one side, a characteristic feature due to the tumor’s renal origin. Mild hematuria may occur as the neoplastic process disrupts normal renal architecture, while hypertension can arise from tumor-induced increases in renin production or vascular compression within the kidney. The imaging study described—a solitary, well-defined mass originating from the kidney with displacement of the renal pelvis—reinforces the diagnosis, as these features distinguish it from other abdominal masses encountered in pediatric patients.

Key learning point: Wilms tumor is the most common renal tumor in children, typically presenting as an abdominal mass with possible metastasis to the lungs, and is characterized by a mass arising from the kidney that displaces the collecting system.

questions.text: A 2-year-old presents with a smooth flank mass that does not cross the midline and microscopic hematuria. Which finding is most strongly associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Wilms tumor, a malignant renal neoplasm, typically presents in children aged 2 to 4 years with a smooth, unilateral flank mass and microscopic hematuria. Hemihypertrophy, characterized by asymmetric overgrowth of one side of the body, is a congenital anomaly associated with Wilms tumor, especially in syndromes like Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. This association highlights genetic and developmental abnormalities in renal embryogenesis, underscoring the importance of early screening and diagnosis in at-risk children.

Key learning point: Wilms tumor is the most common intra-abdominal tumor in children, primarily affecting the kidneys.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated urinary vanillylmandelic acid is associated with neuroendocrine tumors, such as neuroblastoma, not renal tumors. Neuroblastoma often presents with a poorly marginated mass that may cross the midline, unlike the smooth, unilateral flank mass of Wilms tumor.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypsarrhythmia, an EEG pattern seen in West syndrome, is unrelated to renal neoplasms. West syndrome involves neurological symptoms like spasms and developmental regression, not abdominal masses or hematuria.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for tumors with hepatoid or germ cell differentiation, such as yolk sac tumors and hepatoblastomas. It is not associated with renal tumors like Wilms tumor, which do not secrete this marker.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old girl in your clinic for follow-up. Her mother reports that she has had mild abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. On abdominal examination, there is a left-sided, nontender, smooth abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. The remainder of the examination is normal. Complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastoma is the third most common malignancy of childhood; it should be among the differential diagnoses in any child presenting with an abdominal mass. However, neuroblastoma typically manifests before the second year of life as an irregular abdominal mass that often crosses the midline (unlike this patient's mass) and is often associated with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, failure to thrive).

B) INCORRECT:

In children, lymphomas that arise as palpable abdominal masses are typically non-Hodgkin lymphomas of the GI tract, e.g., Burkitt lymphomas. Such large lymphomas usually manifest with concomitant symptoms of mass effect, such as bowel obstruction, intussusception, constipation, or decreased appetite. Additionally, more than 50% of pediatric gastrointestinal lymphomas arise in the ileocecal region, manifesting as an RLQ mass. While lymphoma cannot be entirely excluded in this patient solely based on the findings presented, it is not the most likely cause of an abdominal mass in this 4-year-old girl.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common kidney cancer in adults, but it is rare during childhood and adolescence, accounting for ∼ 2% of all pediatric renal tumors. While RCC can manifest with a palpable mass in the flank or the abdomen, it is usually also associated with hematuria, anemia, and constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fatigue, fever).

D) CORRECT:

Nephroblastoma, or Wilms tumor, should be suspected in a young child with a nontender abdominal mass that does not cross the midline, especially if its surface is smooth, as is the case in this patient. Nephroblastoma is the fourth most common type of childhood cancer, accounting for ∼ 5% of all malignant childhood tumors. The tumor is most commonly an incidental finding on exam, without other signs or symptoms, but may manifest with abdominal pain and hypertension. Laboratory analysis should include a urinalysis, which typically shows hematuria. The best initial diagnostic test is an abdominal ultrasound, which can distinguish nephroblastoma from other abdominal tumors, showing a kidney mass of mostly uniform echogenicity with hypoechoic areas of necrosis. Abdominal CT or MRI is performed to assess the extent of involvement and to help with surgical planning.

Key learning point: Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) typically presents in young children as a smooth, nontender abdominal mass that does not cross the midline and may be associated with hypertension.
Image Description:

MRI abdomen (T2-weighted with fat saturation; coronal plane) of a 3-year-old child

A large heterogeneous but relatively well-circumscribed solid mass is centered within the lower pole of the left kidney. Normal renal tissue is seen cranial to the mass. The hypointense areas of the mass suggest soft tissue, whereas the areas of hyperintensity suggest hemorrhage or necrosis.

Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor), the most common type of pediatric renal cancer, with a peak incidence at 3–4 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) may manifest in some cases as a palpable abdominal mass or a protruding abdomen due to renal enlargement. Cystic diseases of the kidneys account for ∼ 5% of all palpable abdominal masses in children. However, polycystic kidney disease generally involves both kidneys concomitantly and is usually not an incidental finding, but rather manifests with hematuria, signs of renal failure (e.g., electrolyte disturbances, increased serum creatinine and BUN), and/or recurrent urinary tract infections.
questions.hint: This patient's condition may be associated with aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and intellectual disability as part of WAGR syndrome.

questions.text: A healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of an abdominal mass. They report that she has had abdominal pain and decreased appetite for the past 3 weeks, and her abdomen appears more protuberant. On examination, she is playful. Palpation of the right upper quadrant reveals a hard, nontender mass extending about 4 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory results, including complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel, are normal. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) is the most common solid renal tumor in childhood and the most likely cause of an abdominal mass in an otherwise healthy child between the ages of 1 and 5 years. Almost all cases have unilateral kidney involvement and are diagnosed before 10 years of age (mean age, 3 years). Affected children often present with an asymptomatic abdominal mass discovered incidentally by a caregiver or pediatrician, but symptoms can include abdominal distention, anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, fever, and hematuria. About 25% of children with Wilms tumor have hypertension at diagnosis. Unlike neuroblastoma or sarcoma, Wilms tumor rarely invades bone or bone marrow; consequently, patients do not have low blood-cell counts, bone pain, or fractures, even at advanced stages.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of an abdominal mass in an otherwise healthy 3-year-old child with normal vital signs and normal laboratory results is Wilms tumor.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal-cell carcinoma, the most common malignancy of renal origin in adults, is rare in children. When it does occur in this population, it is most commonly seen in older children and adolescents, and they typically present with advanced disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Sarcomas, particularly rhabdomyosarcoma, can manifest in childhood as a painless mass, but these tumors are typically seen in children older than 5 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Although hepatoblastoma is the most common liver tumor in children and the third most common abdominal tumor in children aged 6 months to 3 years, it is a much less frequent diagnosis than either Wilms tumor or neuroblastoma. Patients with hepatoblastoma typically have anemia, thrombocytosis, and elevated aminotransferase levels, none of which are present in this patient. They also tend to have an elevated alpha-fetoprotein level.

E) INCORRECT:

Intussusception (the telescoping of part of the intestine into itself) typically occurs before 2 years of age and often manifests with the triad of colicky abdominal pain, a sausage-shaped abdominal mass in the right upper quadrant, and jelly-red stools. Most patients with intussusception are irritable and have vomiting; about 25% have an abdominal mass. The telescoping of the intestine can be visualized on ultrasound as the classic target sign.
questions.hint: This condition should be suspected in a toddler with a non-tender abdominal mass, especially if it is firm, smooth, and associated with hematuria and/or hypertension.
